subject: Re: [junit] Passing parameters to methods
msgSnippet: ... Well, personally, I ve got no problem with using Method Objects, so the idea of passing parameters in as constructors isn t a big deal. The point, in this
messageBody:
Cedric Beust <cbeust@...> wrote:
> > The major advantage of this technique is that I can easily create
> > tests for lots of valid names. If I'm reading it from a file, the list
> > could be quite extensive _and_ you'll know which names passed the test
> > and which names didn't.
>
> Sure, but you're still simulating passing parameters to methods by passing
> them to your constructors. Not the most intuitive way.

Well, personally, I've got no problem with using Method Objects, so
the idea of passing parameters in as constructors isn't a big deal.
The point, in this scenario, is that your Test is like a Command
pattern; you construct the Test with data, then you tell it to run.

Intuitive? Maybe, maybe not. Personally, I find the idea of having to
clean up state in my tests so that future invocations won't be
contaminated rather counter-intuitive as well. The idea that I have to
have tests run in a particular order to get repeatability strikes me
as odd as well - I can't help but think that exposes me to some
order-dependant bugs that are masked by my tests.

> Out of curiousity: any easy way to do this in TestNG?
> > ("Parameterising" a list or a file name doesn't count; you wouldn't
> > get the easy reporting of the bad values vs the good values).
>
> Yes, with @Factory.

Thanks...

Have you thought about an option like this?

@ParameterList({ "oneName" }, {"anotherName"}, {"aThirdName"})
@Test
public void testSingleString(String firstName) {
...
}

The vast majority of times I want a parameterised test, I don't really
want a _lot_ of parameters, but I'm not sure I'd want to muck around
with defining the parameters in the XML either; I can tell you
outright that the major reason I don't even want to think about
converting a serious project to TestNG is that the XML file is a turn
off.

Robert.
